Biddy EarlyAbout 80 years ago there was an old woman supposed to be living in east Clare by the name of Biddy Early.  Whenever a person was unusually ill or in danger of death someone used to go to Biddy looking for a cure.  She would look through a bottle & tell them whether the person would recover or not and tell them what to do & sometimes she told the person who came to them that the patient would be dead when the person would go home. 4583308/4578392/4587814.title: Biddy Early
4583308/4578392/4587814.text:
Biddy Early was an old woman who lived near Feakle long ago. She was supposed to be a witch and she could tell fortunes and cure people. any one that would be very sick they would go to her and she would cure them. She was able to tell them how many windows in their house and if there was a broken pane of glass on the window of their house. If there was broken delph in the house she would tell them to throw it out, that it was not lucky to have it. She was to have a bottle and that when she would look into it she would see the devil. If she would come into the house and you churning she would take the butter. She was an old travelling woman who used to go round from house to house.

4583308/4578396/4587830.title: Biddy Early and the Cow
4583308/4578396/4587830.text: Long ago there was a heifier gone from Mike Glynn's father. He was searching for her in every place till at last he was tired searching. "I will never get her" he said. About a week after he was talking to Biddy Early about the heifier. The heifier was gone three weeks now. Biddy Early said to Mike Glynn father "Get up early on Sunday morning and stand outside your door and look southwards. The first field you'll see with a flock of cattle grazing in it, your heifier will be there." The first field he saw with a flock of cattle grazing in it was abroad in Clare. But he went to Clare and got his heifier where Biddy Early told him. He brought her home and she died that same year.

4583308/4578397/4587833.title: Biddy Early and the Butter
4583308/4578397/4587833.text:
If Biddy Early came into a house and the people churning she would take the butter from them. One time there was an old woman out in Clare. She had the finest "bawn" of cows you could lay eyes on and during one week not a bit of butter would come in the churn if she was churning till morning. Nothing but froth and an awful smell out of it. There was a calf after dying on the woman's neighbour. Biddy Early had the dead calf dug up and buried in the woman's land. While the dead calf was in the land she couldn't get any bit of the butter. She told the priest about Biddy Early and he hunted her out of the place. From that time Biddy Early lived near Feakle and before that she lived near Lough Grainne.
(continues on next page)

When Biddy Early was dying she threw the bottle into the Shannon and she died Catholic.Her house is still to be seen between Tulla and Feackle. It is said that a woman called Moll Anthony took Biddy Early's place but she had a black book with her magic in it.

When my father was a youngster Biddy Early the famous Clare witch was living in Feakle. She had been excommunicated by that time and people were afraid to visit her. As well the journey from Kilmaley to Feakle was a trying one so altogether my father knew only three people who consulted her.One was his uncle another James O'Grady. he went to Feakle when my father was about two years old - about the year 1859. He did not go on his own behalf however. He went with a neighbour named Keatinge. Keatinge had no horse and as well he did not know a word of English while Biddy was believed to know no Irish so my grand-uncle had to act as interpreter.Keatinge's son went to Ennis one Saturday shortly before that. he brought in a sack of potatoes on a donkey's back and sold them. Afterwards he returned home apparently in the best of health but next morning he got a stroke of paralysis and could not move hand or foot. His neighbours decided that it was a "fairy stroke" and advised his father to consult Biddy and my granduncle volunteered to bring him to Feakle.When they got to the witch's house Biddy saluted by grand uncle. "Your are welcome Mr OGrady" said she. "You have been improving your house lately but you have not finished the job yet." "I have done all I mean to do."

A family named Kearney lived quite close to us in Kilmaley a good many years ago. They owned a small farm of very poor land, no part of which touched a main road or even a boithrín. Worse still two streams flowed round it in such a way as to cut it off from the two nearest main roads. The result was that old Kearney could not draw home his turf and make a rick of it near his house - these was no way for a horse and car to get in. My grand uncle however gave him a site in which to make a rick of turf, and he used to make the rick there, and then every Saturday one of his daughters used spend the day drawing home turf from the rick in an ass and baskets - the ass of course had to trot through a shallow part of one of the streams. 4769950/4762433/4819294.title: Scéal Eile
4769950/4762433/4819294.text: Sgeale eile.Another person from our neighbourhood who consulted Biddy Early was a man named Griffin. His sister was married to my father's uncle.When Griffin was about fifteen or sixteen - more than seventy years ago, his father sent him out one morning early before breakfast to look after some young cattle they had out on the mountain, a good bit away from the house. [Mountain in Clare means a moor]The youngster returned in a dreadful state after an hour or two. He said that when he was on the mountain he met a black man the blackest man he ever say; and that without speaking a word the stranger caught him and beat him unmercifully. The youngster was put to bed but instead of improving he got worse and as usual the neighbour disposed "a fairy stroke," and advised a visit to Biddy Early.When old Griffin reached Feable, Biddy was able to tell him what had happened to his son. She gave him a bottle of stuff which was supposed to cure the boy and she also told the father never to allow the child and of the house until he had eaten some foodFrom that time on Griffin never left his house fasting except when he going to Holy Communion and then he took care to have others with him.

4769950/4762434/4819297.text:
About the time that Biddy Early lived in Feakle, a Miss Hodge lived in Kilrush. At that time an extraordinary number of dogs suffered from rabies. and people lived in hourly dread of getting hydrophobia. Miss Hodge claimed to be able to prevent hydrophobia. She had a crystal  and when she looked into it she could see (so she said) the mad dog hanging off the person he had bitten, and hanging from the part he bit. If he was hanging from below the heart she claimed to be able to set a charm which would prevent hydrophobia, but she could  do nothing, if he bit above the heart. Miss Hodge was a Protestant - some said she was a minister's daughter - and like Biddy Early she knew no Irish. Apparently it is easier to indulge in "hocus pocus" through the medium of English than through Gaedhealg. No bonus for Irish in the nether world!Some  years before my grandfather got married - say 85 years ago - he and two other farmers who had horses went to help a poor man named Keatinge (the father of Baitiléar a Phluic) to get home his turf. 4921932/4911016/4931187.text: Biddy Early was a woman who was well known here a long time ago. she used to visit every farmer's house in the parish.One day, while in one of the houses, a neighbour came in. 4922084/4850767/4943007.text: There lived about 80 years ago in Cratloe an old woman named Biddy Early who was supposed to possess supernatural powers or be in league with the devil. 4922096/4852130/4946795.text: My grand-uncle sitting at the fire one night about seventy years ago when he hard a call at the door. He went out to see who was there and there was no-one to be seen. After that he got ill and took to his bed. It was impossible for any doctor to cure him so he heard of a woman whose nam was "Biddy Early." She was able to cure every disease. He went to Biddy and she asked him why hadn't he come sooner. She gave him a bottle and told him to be carefull going home for fear that it would get broken. Clare to visit Biddy Early to ask her questions about some business that had gone wrong with him. As Michael O'Brien stood on the doorstep she said how are you Michael O'Brien. How are ye all in Coolcappa. He got so frightened that he came home without asking her any questions and he never had anything to do with fortune telling after that.

4922104/4852448/4948504.title: Biddy Early and the Tory Hill Orchardman
4922104/4852448/4948504.text: All the fields around Tory Hill house were orchards. An orchard-man had a cabin built against the "House of Prayer" and his duty was to watch the orchards, the fruits of which were in the "House of Prayer." The man demanded from the priest a gun with which to protect himself. He got the gun.One night the orchard-man was very tired on retiring and he slept heavily. A red-haired man entered and stole the gun as a joke. The priest then took the man's two pigs - which were then kept for two harvests and allowed to graze in the fields - in compensation for the gun. The man aggrieved went to Biddy Early. She cut the cards for him, but failed to divine his loss. She asked him if it were iron metal or steel, but he refused to answer at first. Finally, he told her that it was wood and iron. She then cut the cards again and told him of his loss and where to find it by nettles in a rabbit burrow, but that he should remove his coat to get his arm in far enough to recover the gun. He did as directed and procured the gun which he returned to its owner, and he got back his two pigs. Fr. Hartnett used to charge 10/- yearly to those who would take grass for a goat on the hill

4922044/4846939/4952429.title: Death of Mrs Early
4922044/4846939/4952429.text: She lived to be ninety seven years and she sent for the priest. The priests hated her because they considered her a witch and they used be warning their congregation not to show strangers where she lived. She sent for the priest in her death-bed and the priest refused to go to her. She sent for him the second time and he refused. She sent a third time to say that she could not die without seeing the priest that she had information to give them that would benefit both priests and people during the world. Nobody knows what passed between them but there were twenty seven parish priests in her funeral - all the parish priests in County Clare. The following Sunday the priest spoke of her to his Congregation. He said, "we thought we had a demon amongst us in poor Mrs. Early but we had a saint and we did not know it. She gave us information that will save both ourselves and our people to the end of time. She often got herself in trouble to save men of my own tribe." It was the general belief, at the time she died that it was in her information the Prayers after Mass were started.

5079720/4878814/5079975.title: Biddy Early
5079720/4878814/5079975.text: There was an old woman in East Clare by the name of Biddy Early. She was a witch and she was supposed to be able to cure every disease and on account of that the people of Clare went to her when they were in trouble and she would tell them what they wanted without they telling her and her cure was a bottle and a little man inside it and if the little man was standing the cure would be successful but when the little man was lying down the cure would not be successful but this rarely happened. There was a farmer living near Biddy Early and every morning some of his cattle were dead. At last he went to the witch and as soon as she saw him she told him his trouble without he telling her and he asked would she give him a cure. She told him that there was a well near his house which was poisoned and if he covered the well no more of his cattle would die. He went home and covered the well and no more of his cattle died. When at last she was evicted by her landlord, she cursed the landlord and said he would go like the froth of the river and it came true.

5079720/4878824/5080020.title: Biddy Early
5079720/4878824/5080020.text: When Biddy Early's landlord was evicting his tenants the witch asked a farmer to cart away some furniture for her. The farmer agreed to do it if she let him know the cure she had. The witch assured him that she would show him the cure. The farmer took away half the furniture and when he came back for the other half he wanted to see the cure. The witch got a bottle and told the man to look into it and he should see whether he would be lucky or not for his life. The man looked into the bottle and saw a little man inside when he told this to the witch she told him he and his descendants would be very lucky. The man took away the other half of the furniture then and when the landlord came he became very indignant and he took the bottle the witch tried to recover it and told the landlord that he would be sorry if broke it he did not heed her word and he broke the bottle then the witch cursed the landlord and said he go like the froth of the river and there is not a trace of him now.

5080332/4878980/5083634.title: Biddy Early - Hidden Treasure
5080332/4878980/5083634.text: It was said that money was hid in a certain fort. People went to Biddy Early. She told them that the money was hid there right enough, but when they would dig for it, there were to make sure that nobody would curse or swear. When they went to dig for it, one of the men was digging with a spade. He hit the cover off the pot and he swore a great oath that he had got the money as they were told that the money was hid in a pot. No sooner had he cursed than a bellowing bull came running towards them until they were outside the ditch of the field and then he stopped. The fort had got its name from that day to this as Lisín an Airgead.

When he was coming along the road the horse stopped to take a drink, When he bent down, the bottle fell out and when he went home his wife was dead.

5080332/4879062/5084219.title: Stories about Biddy Early
5080332/4879062/5084219.text: One day my great grand father John O'Neill was ploughing in a field in Coolmeen. When he was in the middle of the garden he saw two women dressed in pure white walking across the headland and they went out into the next field. When my great grand father got to the end of the "scribe". He left the plough and got up in the wall to see where were they, and couldn't see the sign of the women that had just passed over. That evening he got a stroke and doctors were sent for and they could not do him any good. Then they went to Biddy Early and she said she could not do anything for him that they did not come in time. He died.

5080332/4879063/5084220.text: One time a man in Labsheeda had an only son and he was very sick. His father was told to go to Biddy Early for a cure, which he did accompanied by another man. She also said he had been over looked by a fair haired young lady a few weeks before that. When they went home they found out that the boy had died at the exact hour that Biddy told them.

In olden times there dwelt in this land of ours many people who were skilled in witchcraft, among them being a well-known woman by the name of "Biddy Early". 4922169/4858040/5130182.text: There were a great many witches in the country in olden times. They were great to cure people who got fairy blasts. One local witch was Biddy Early and she lived under an eye of a bridge in Limerick.There was a person one time who got a fairy blast and friends belonging to the person went to the witch for a cure. They had a very long journey to go and they were getting tired and sure they began to curse the witch. When they arrived at the bridge where the witch was they told her all about the patient. She said to them, "ye're coming to me now for a cure and ye couldn't afford a good word for me on ye're journey.They denied that they said anything about so she surprised them when she told them the exact words they said. She told them they had a four year old horse at home in the stable and she said "when ye go home the horse will take a terrible pain but ye're not to do anything for her. 5162140/5157884/5199364.title: A Story
5162140/5157884/5199364.text: We hear many people talk of Biddy Early but those people do not know how she came to the world or how she got this bottle which she had in her possession but it is a very interesting story. Long ago there was a little girl and  her name was Biddy Early. She was very fond of wandering away from home. It fell dark and she turned home. As she was passing this fort she heard all the music and dancing inside and she was astonished, she went in and there were a lot of people inside dancing and singing. She sat down and enjoyed herself also and never thought about going home and spent the night there and at four o'clock in the morning when the cock crew all the people scattered in every direction but they left beside Biddy a bottle which was a gift to her during her life because every time she wanted to know anything she need only look into and she would know everything that she wished. When Biddy died some people say that the bottle got broken, but we do not know exactly what happened to it. .
